Q1.

Unlevered Beta and CAPM (Using Business Risk Only)

A firm has levered beta = 1.73, D/E = 0.75, tax rate = 24%.
What is its unlevered (asset) beta? (Use the standard formula removing leverage.)

‚úÖ Why this is the answer: Unlevered beta measures business risk only (no financial leverage).
We ‚Äústrip out‚Äù leverage using: Œ≤U = Œ≤L / [1 + (1 ‚Äì T) √ó (D/E)].
This lets us compare firms on operating risk, independent of capital structure.
Your numbers: Œ≤U = 1.73 / [1 + (1 ‚àí 0.24) √ó 0.75] = 1.1.

If the risk-free rate is 3% and the expected market return is 10%, what is the expected return using CAPM with the unlevered beta?

‚úÖ CAPM intuition: Investors require compensation for time value (Rf) and for bearing market risk (Œ≤ √ó MRP).
We use the unlevered beta to price the business risk without leverage:
E[R] = Rf + Œ≤U √ó (Rm ‚àí Rf) = 10.71%.
This gives a baseline cost of equity for the project/asset before financing effects.

Q2.

WACC and Value Creation Threshold

A firm has Equity = $284m, Debt = $222m, Re = 11.4%, Rd = 5.8%, Tax = 29%.
Compute the WACC (after tax).

‚úÖ Concept: WACC is the blended required return from shareholders and debtholders, after the interest tax shield.
Formula: WACC = (E/V)¬∑Re + (D/V)¬∑Rd¬∑(1 ‚àí T).
Your numbers: WACC = (284/506)√ó11.4% + (222/506)√ó5.8%√ó(1‚àí29%) = 8.21%.

Suppose a project in this firm has expected return = 11.6%.
By how many percentage points does the project‚Äôs return exceed the WACC? (This gap signals value creation if positive.)

‚úÖ Decision rule: If Project Return > WACC, the project creates value (positive NPV under proportional scaling).
Your numbers: Gap = 11.6% ‚àí 8.21% = 3.39 pp. A positive gap indicates the project clears the firm‚Äôs opportunity cost of capital.

Q3.

Comparable Company Method: Unlever and Relever Beta

A comparable firm has Œ≤ = 1.07, D/E = 0.31, tax = 25%.
(a) Compute the unlevered beta for the business.

‚úÖ Step 1 (remove leverage): Œ≤U = Œ≤L / [1 + (1 ‚àí T) √ó (D/E)] ‚Üí business-only risk.
Your numbers: 1.07 / [1 + (1 ‚àí 0.25) √ó 0.31] = 0.87.

(b) Your target firm will finance the project at D/E = 0.99. Compute the relevered beta to be used in CAPM.

‚úÖ Step 2 (apply target leverage): Œ≤L = Œ≤U √ó [1 + (1 ‚àí T) √ó (D/E)].
Your numbers: 0.8682 √ó [1 + (1 ‚àí 0.25) √ó 0.99] = 1.51.
This aligns the project‚Äôs risk with your capital structure.

Q4.

Portfolio Beta and Cost of Capital

A two-asset portfolio invests 33% in Asset A (Œ≤ = 1.23) and 67% in Asset B (Œ≤ = 1.13).
Compute the portfolio beta.

‚úÖ Aggregation rule: Portfolio beta is the value-weighted average of component betas: Œ≤p = Œ£ wiŒ≤i.
Your numbers: 33%√ó1.23 + 67%√ó1.13 (scaled to weights) ‚Üí 1.163.

With Rf = 4% and Rm = 12%, compute the portfolio‚Äôs cost of capital via CAPM.

‚úÖ CAPM logic: Required return rises with systematic risk (Œ≤).
E[Rp] = Rf + Œ≤p(Rm ‚àí Rf) = 13.3%.
Interpretation: this is the portfolio‚Äôs opportunity cost of capital.

Q5.

Relevering Beta ‚Äì Aurora Technologies

Aurora Technologies has an asset beta of 0.87.
Its debt-to-equity ratio is 1.52, and the corporate tax rate is 24.76%.

‚úÖ Equity Beta = Œ≤A √ó [1 + (1 ‚Äì tax) √ó D/E] = 1.86.
This accounts for financial leverage amplifying the risk borne by equity holders.

Q6.

Cost of Debt Capital ‚Äì CAPM and Default Approach

‚úÖ Expected Return (CAPM) = r_f + Œ≤ √ó MRP = 4.61%.
‚úÖ Expected Return (Default Method) = YTM ‚àí Default Probability √ó Loss Rate = 6.64%.
Q7.

Portfolio Beta with Multiple Divisions

An institutional investor holds two divisions of Aurora Technologies:
- Division A weight = 71.07%, beta = 1.28
- Division B weight = 28.93%, beta = 0.65

‚úÖ Portfolio Beta = wAŒ≤A + wBŒ≤B = 1.1.
This shows how different risk exposures combine in a weighted portfolio.

Q8.

After-tax Cost of Debt

Aurora Technologies issues new bonds with a yield to maturity of 6.6%.
The corporate tax rate is 24.93%.

‚úÖ After-tax cost of debt = rD √ó (1 ‚Äì tax) = 4.95%.
Interest is tax-deductible, so the effective cost of debt is lower than the nominal rate.

Q9.

Project-specific Discount Rate

Aurora Technologies considers investing in a high-risk digital platform.
- Risk-free rate = 3.1%
- Market risk premium = 5.65%
- Project beta = 1.44

‚úÖ Discount Rate = rf + Œ≤project √ó MRP = 11.25%.
Projects with higher betas require higher discount rates to compensate investors for risk.
